DOC.HEAD: Letter of Intent With IMF Completed, Poles Say
DOC.TEXT: The government and International Monetary Fund on Tuesday finished drafting a letter of intent on an economic adjustment plan leading to $700 million in standby loans to Poland, a Finance Ministry official said. The letter should be signed after it is reviewed by senior government officials, said Deputy Finance Minister Janusz Sawicki, dismissing suggestions that a delay had arisen. ``There are no disappointments. I can say it is going on schedule,'' Sawicki said. ``Of course, you could always wish for miracles.'' An IMF mission headed by European Department head Massimo Russo left Poland on Tuesday after completing the agreement that requires Poland to embark on tough economic reforms to get the IMF credits. There was no reason to initial the letter right away, said Sawicki, who took part in the negotiations on the Polish side. Asked whether the IMF aid will arrive in time to assist Poland as it undertakes economic reform scheduled to begin Jan. 1, Sawicki said several Western countries probably would offer a bridge loan in the interim before the first IMF installment arrives. He said he also hoped a $1 billion stabilization loan being prepared by Western countries to back the Polish currency would be ready early next year. ``Every hour is now being counted,'' he said. The letter of intent is to be reviewed by senior members of the Solidarity-led government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki before its signing, Sawicki said. After it is signed, it is to be sent to IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus and the IMF board of executive directors in Washington. Deputy Prime Minister Leszek Balcerowicz and Polish National Bank president Wladyslaw Baka will sign the letter for the Polish side, the state PAP news agency reported. The agreement, which Mazowiecki's government has been negotiating since it took office in September, is tied to the sweeping economic reform program that the governent introduced in parliament Sunday. It calls for strict measures to balance the budget, decontrol prices, limit wages, break monopolies, introduce partial convertibility of the zloty and privatize state industries. The agreement will certify to Western leaders that Poland is making serious efforts to put its economy in order, and is expected to result immediately in $300 million in World Bank loans and about $3 billion in other Western aid. The holders of Poland's $40 billion Western debt also are expected to agree to rescheduling part of that debt. The progress in talks with the IMF came on the third day of a Parliament debate concerning the radical economic reform program Balcerowicz submitted Sunday. For the second straight day, the debate was dominated by deputies from rural areas complaining the budget does not do enough to help farmers obtain agricultural inputs such as farm machinery, pesticides and fertilizers, and that the government should set minimum prices for farm produce. Agriculture Minister Czeslaw Janicki said he sympathized with many of the complaints about lack of government funds for agriculture. But he said that the state's finances would not allow anymore at present. ``It is impossible to do everything overnight,'' he said. As the Sejm, or lower house of Parliament, debated throughout the day, a 43-member extraordinary commission set up to review the government's economic package was meeting behind closed doors. Deputies said the commission would be doing much of the real work on analyzing the package, which would then be put to a vote of the full Sejm sometime after Christmas.
